resources.string: Nova Scotia Provincial Employee Emergency Guide
This application is intended for use by employees of the Province of Nova Scotia
Please check your email and enter the verification token provided.
Please enter a Nova Scotia government email.
Sorry the token you have entered is incorrect. Please try again.
You must re-validate your email address. Open the app to send the verification email.
Problems, concerns or suggestions? Please contact corporate Security.

During regular working hours the Floor Emergency Wardens are available to assist you and direct the response to crisis events. Outside of regular hours, at remote locations, and while on the road, employees are reminded to have a “working alone” plan. Your supervisor should be aware of your work location and you should be aware of supports available to you to respond to unusual events.
These are trusted social media source for additional information.
The Province of NS Storm line will be updated at 6 am each morning when severe weather is expected.
1.Check road and weather conditions before travelling. Contact your supervisor for guidance before travelling.
2.If you are at work, stay in the building until direction from your Manager or Floor Emergency Wardens.
3.Once the storm has past, report injuries or damage to Floor Emergency wardens or first responders. Complete a departmental incident report. Notify your Manager of any issues immediately.
4.When exiting the building, beware of downed power lines, broken glass, and unsafe areas.
If this is an emergency contact 911
2.Witnessed or were a victim of a crime or violence on government property
3.Want to report a suspicious activity or security issue
The 911 service is there to support you during traumatic events.
injured or at immediate risk of being injured
There is an immediate threat to yourself or others
If you are concerned that an event could turn violent
Call for help, alert your supervisor,peers or Floor Wardens if available
Remove yourself from the threat if possible
Once the event is under control contact Security and your department safety office or Health and safety committee.
If a Demonstration Occurs Outside the Building or in the Lobby
Do not, under any circumstances, involve yourself with the demonstrators either verbally or physically.
If the demonstrators prevent entry to your work location, withdraw and inform your supervisor.
Immediately secure all sensitive documentation and equipment.
Do not say or do anything that will agitate the occupiers.
Do not attempt to physically restrain the occupiers.
Contact your Supervisor and Corporate Security. Wait for further direction.
1. Do NOT trigger a fire alarm unless there is an actual fire.
4. Notify those in your immediate vicinity.
5. Set all cellphones/smartphones to silent (not vibrate).
6. Run -Evacuate if possible, avoiding open areas and hallways.
7. Hide -If you cannot evacuate, find a safe place, barricade the door
8. Fight -If you are discovered, as a last resort you can Fight. Defend yourself with whatever makeshift weapon you can find in your workspace.
1. Remain calm. Notify your supervisor and Building Maintenance of the situation, and allow them to investigate further.
2. Outside of regular hours you are advised to contact your supervisor. If you feel there is an immediate threat within the building, evacuate and call 911.
3. Instructions during normal hours will vary depending on situation, they may include evacuation, shelter in place, or no action. You should be ready to respond.
2.Stay where you are and enact shelter in place procedures.
3.Remain in your building and monitor emails and phone calls for further instructions.
Sometimes odours may be a sign of significant hazard. I.e. natural gas.
If you are in a Collision
Prevent further injury, conduct First Aid, Call 911.
Exchange contact information with others involved.
Contact your insurance company (have number in your phone)
1. Set all light fixtures, equipment, and appliances switches to the OFF position to protect them when the power comes back on.
2. During normal hours remain in place and await instructions from your Manager, Floor Emergency Wardens or Security.
3. Outside of regular hours you are encouraged to evacuate the building immediately. Emergency lighting will last only up to 30 min.
4. Do not attempt to use the elevator.Report all persons who may be trapped in elevators.
1. Use emergency call button or phone inside the elevator, or a cell phone, to contact building maintenance and/or security.
2. Give your name and contact information, and specific location —building, elevator location or number, floor.
3. Wait for rescue. Be patient. Technician has to get to you, then take time to get you out.
4. Reassure others trapped with you, ask them to stay calm, and tell them what you have learned about the rescue plan.
Shout “Fire, Fire, Fire” to draw attention to the threat
Activate the nearest pull station, usually by an exit door
Only attempt to fight the fire if you feel confident in your ability to extinguish it, you have the correct fire extinguisher, and a clear exit path.
Exit immediately by the nearest unblocked stairwell
Call 911 when safe to do so
Report to your assembly/muster point and await further direction
Do not re-enter the building until given the all clear by authorities
When the alarm sounds, exit the building immediately. Some buildings may have a two stage alarm system. Follow local directions form your Floor wardens.

Assist those with mobility issues to seek an area of refuge near or in stairwells, assign a “buddy” and alert authorities of the situation. Do not attempt to carry anyone down the stairs unless there is an immediate threat to life.

Bomb threats can be received in a variety of ways. Most bomb threats are made by persons who want to create an atmosphere of general anxiety or panic. All such threats must be taken seriously and handled as though a bomb is in the building.
1. Remain Calm, Listen to the caller, be calm and courteous. Do not interrupt the caller.Try to keep the caller on the line.
2. Without upsetting caller, try to obtain as much information as possible. Ask questions, such as “Where is the bomb?”, “When is it going to go off?” “What kind is it?”, “What does it look like?”
3. Take notes on what is said and your observations about background noise, voice, language, etc.
4. Notify someone in the office while the call is still ongoing. They should contact 911 or 9 –911.
5. Initiate call trace action (if available) while the call is ongoing (*57).
6. Follow any instructions given by your Supervisor, Security, or First Responders.
7. At the direction of 911, pull the fire alarm.
If you find or receive a suspicious object, package, or mail:
1. Remain Calm. Do not touch or move the object.
2. If you are holding the object gently set it down on a solid surface or on the floor.
3. Do not cover it.Do not attempt to disarm it.
4. Close doors to reduce air flow, and isolate the area.
5. Alert your supervisor and Security if available.
7. Call 911 or 9-911 from government phones when safe to do so
8. If you come in contact with package contents,
1. Remain where you are and close the doors.
2. Await further instructions from First Responders.
Otherwise, leave the immediate area and remain out of the area until told you can return.
1. Call for help! Ask someone to notify the Floor Emergency Warden, get First Aid Kit and AED (Automated External Defibrillator) immediately.
2.Complete a scene survey and make the area safe.
3. Call 911 or 9-911, if someone else is nearby have them do it for you. Have caller follow dispatcher’s instructions.
4. Assess Airway, Breathing, Circulation (ABCs) – immediately start CPR if necessary and utilize an AED
5. If possible have someone meet the ambulance at the building address and bring them to you.
6. Continue CPR until directed by First Responders (note -sometimes First Responders may wish assistance with patient care).
7.Complete your departmental Incident Report and inform your manager.
1. Remain calm and call out for help. Call or have someone call 911 or 9-911.
2.Complete a scene survey and make the area safe.
3. Stay with the injured or ill person and await emergency services.
4. Provide first aid for the injuries.
"5. Do not attempt to move injured person, unless they are in imminent danger. "
6. Do not transport in personal vehicle unless directed by paramedics.
7 Stay with the injured person until First Responders arrive.
8 Complete a departmental Incident Report and inform your Manager.
1. Remain calm. Ask for consent from the individual to provide first aid.
2. Locate a Floor Emergency Warden or first aider.
4. Provide first aid for the injuries.
5. If medical attention is required but no ambulance necessary, take the individual to the hospital or clinic by taxi. Or wait with them while a loved one picks them up. Do NOT use personal vehicles.
6. Do not send injured person alone and insist that they do not drive themselves to seek treatment.
7. Inform your Manager and complete a departmental Incident Report.
Be aware of unusual behaviour. Advise your manager if you have concerns.
Crisis first aid for acute stress reaction.
1) Let the person tell their story, if they want.
3) Validate normal responses to abnormal events.
5) Suggest they avoid alcohol or drugs.
If you have been involved in an accident please call Risk Management (24/7):
Wait for further directions, remain in current location.
Precautionary measures in response to a threat/incident in the general vicinity of your building.
When the threat is to the structure and/or could cause harm to those inside.
When the threat is external and the structure is the safest place to be.
When the threat is to people, avoid the threat by any means. Run, Hide, Fight.
In all events your manager must be notified as soon as possible. If your building has security personnel notify them as well.

To add a quick link for a contact, go to the main screen of your android device and hold your finger down on empty space. When a screen pops up press widgets, then contacts. Click the option to add a direct Dial widget, drag the widget onto the screen and select the contact you want to create a direct dial for. Your direct dial widget is now set up.
Your first point of contact for emergency events should be your manager, then building security if available. We suggest having these numbers available on your phone. You can do this by:
\u2022 Have been involved in a collision while driving a fleet vehicle or a personal vehicle for work purposes
\u2022 Are a witness to an incident involving crown property
Non-emergencies only. If you require immediate assistance call 911.
Province of Nova Scotia – Emergency Preparedness Safety App (the “App”) Terms and Conditions of Use

The Province (hereinafter, “We”) realize that the Terms and Conditions of Use (the “Agreement”) can be confusing, so, to the right of each term, we have provided a summary in “plain English”. The summary does not in any way replace, modify or limit the full text, so please ensure you read the full text as well.

Thank you for choosing the Province’s Emergency Preparedness Safety App. This App is provided to the Province’s employees for convenience, free of charge and its use is completely voluntary. This App does not replace the existing 911 emergency system. In the event of an emergency, dial “911”. \n\n By using or accessing the App, or clicking on the “I Agree” button below, you, as the user of the App (hereinafter “You”) agree to these terms and conditions (the “Terms”), all of which survive the termination of your right to use the App.

Except as expressly stated in this Agreement, We do not make any representation or warranty (express or implied) in respect of the App, or related services offered by or through the App to You, including, without limitation, any implied warranty: (i) of merchantability; (ii) of fitness for a particular purpose; (iii) arising from a course of performance, course of dealing, or usage of trade; (iv) of non-infringement of third party rights; or (v) against hidden defects. The App and the services are provided on an “as is”, “with all faults” and “as available” basis and without any further warranties of any kind. We make no warranty as to the quality or accuracy in respect of the App or the services offered by or through the App. We make no warranty that operation of the App or the service will be uninterrupted or error free or that any defects will be corrected. 


Without limiting the above, you acknowledge that: 

 • You are using the App and the services at your own risk;

 • The App or the service is not a substitute for professional advice or the existing 911 system;

 • You are solely responsible for the use of the App and service and agree that any training or learning on how to use the App or the service is your sole responsibility; which would typically require you to undertake additional and comprehensive gap analysis and risk assessments of the App and the service; and

 • You have not relied on any representation in using the App or the service or any goods and services from us.


To the maximum extent permitted by law, we exclude completely all liability whatsoever for any claims, liability, loss or damage of any kind however caused (including negligence) arising out of or in connection with the services provided by us including the App and its access, use or performance, including, without limitation, we are not liable for: (a) misuse of the App or the services; (b) use of the App or the service with third party data, software or hardware which is incompatible with the App or the service and/or not recommended by us; (c) reduced performance or non-availability of the App or the service as a result of network connections; (d) errors in the App or the service resulting from your configuration or manipulation of the App or the service, in each case not specifically recommended in writing by us; or (e) errors or reduced performance relating to any hardware used to access the App. 


Under no circumstances (including but not limited to any act or omission on our part) will we be liable for any loss or damages (including, without limitation, indirect, incidental, special or consequential or punitive damages and damages for loss of profits) whatsoever which result from any use, or any inability to use, the App or the service. 


To the maximum extent permitted by law, our liability for breach of any implied warranty or condition which cannot be excluded is limited at our option to supply of the good or service ordered by You again or paying for their resupply. 


Notwithstanding the above, to the maximum extent permitted by law, in no event shall our aggregate liability for any claims arising out of or related to these Terms exceed the greater of fifty Canadian dollars ($50) or the amount that You paid, if any, to us for access to or use of the App or service during the six months period immediately prior to the event giving rise to such liability.

Thank you for choosing the Province of Nova Scotia (the “Province”) Emergency Preparedness Safety App. This App is provided to the Province’s employees for convenience, free of charge and its use is completely voluntary. 


By using or accessing the App, or clicking on the “I Accept” button below, you agree to these terms and conditions: 


• The App or the service is not a substitute for professional advice or the existing 911 system

 • Except as expressly stated in this Agreement, we do not make any representation or warranty (express or implied) in respect of the App

 • You are using the App and the services at your own risk

 • You are solely responsible for the use of the App and service

 • All additional terms and conditions can be found in the Terms and Conditions page
